 The truth is, it's actually rare for labels like "conservative" and "liberal" to apply well to people. People tend to be pretty multi-faceted in their ideologies: often people might be 'conservative' on some issues but 'moderate' on others. 
 
 Added to this is the complication that those very terms are not concrete to begin with. Who says "liberal" really means "pro-women" anyway? Or why should we assume "conservative" means NOT being pro-women? I'd say Bush IS conservative in a number of ways (though not with spending!), but I'd also say that his willingness to appoint women to these positions is part of his conservative outlook. This idea that "liberal" and "progressive" are somehow synonymous simply isn't necessarily true.

That's a commonly held misconception about increasing minimum wage levels. In most cases those on the lower end of the economic heap are forced to absorb product cost increases driven by minimum wage increases. As Jo Bennett points out, those are generally internal service sector jobs. Increasing wages there merely increases internal transaction amounts, with no value added to allow additional consumption or provide capital for more jobs.

 
 Not really, that would require to costs of goods poor by minimum wage earners to be entirely made up of the costs of employing minimum wage earners, which is simply not the case. For example, a shoe shop chain I worked for spent a little over 10% of its turnover on wages. If it had doubled the pay of everyone on minimum wage, then that proportion would still have been less than 20% of turnover, which would have perhaps meant a 10% increases in prices. Admittedly there are knock effects if the supply chain is in the same country, but nothing like enough to cancel out the wage increase. Also a lot of the services provided by these jobs, such as childcare, are bought almost exclusively by the middle classes.
